metadata.title: AMIRNET English Questions Database - Part 2
metadata.description: Extracted English questions from Israeli Psychometric Exams

questions.question: The peregrine falcon can reach a speed of 200 miles per hour, faster than ____ member of the animal kingdom.
questions.correctAnswer: any other

questions.question: The butterfly fish can leap out of the water and soar through the air, ____ its fins like wings.
questions.correctAnswer: flapping

questions.question: The collection of rare books and manuscripts from Tibet housed in the National Library of Mongolia is ____, comprising more than a million items.
questions.correctAnswer: immense

questions.question: Oil-based paints are more difficult to distribute ____ over the surface of a wall than latex paints.
questions.correctAnswer: evenly

questions.question: President Franklin D. Roosevelt's middle ____ stands for "Delano".
questions.correctAnswer: initial

questions.question: The compositions of twentieth-century musician John Zorn ____ elements from jazz, klezmer, and punk rock.
questions.correctAnswer: incorporate

questions.question: In Jerusalem's Machane Yehuda market, over 250 ____ sell everything from fruit and vegetables to clothing and household goods.
questions.correctAnswer: vendors

questions.question: In 1923, Italian leader Benito Mussolini was knighted by Britain's King George V, but the honour was ____ when Mussolini declared war on Britain in 1940.
questions.correctAnswer: revoked

questions.question: Gold is virtually indestructible.
options: Gold is extremely difficult to find.
Gold almost never loses its value.
Gold is the most desirable metal.
Gold is nearly impossible to destroy.
questions.correctAnswer: Gold is nearly impossible to destroy.

questions.question: World War II provided tremendous impetus for U.S. industries.
options: World War II changed the infrastructure of U.S. industries.
World War II presented unique challenges to U.S. industries.
U.S. industries were adapted to meet the military's needs in World War II.
U.S. industries were significantly boosted by World War II.
questions.correctAnswer: U.S. industries were significantly boosted by World War II.

questions.question: British historian John Anthony Crook is of the opinion that the high repute of Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius is misplaced.
options: Crook has expressed contradictory views of Marcus Aurelius' role in history.
Crook argues that Marcus Aurelius is one of the most misunderstood individuals in history.
According to Crook, Marcus Aurelius is not deserving of his renown.
Crook argues that Marcus Aurelius has not been given the attention fitting for a figure of his stature.
questions.correctAnswer: According to Crook, Marcus Aurelius is not deserving of his renown.

questions.question: The Opium Wars were precipitated by China's efforts to suppress the opium trade.
options: The Opium Wars broke out as a result of China's efforts to regulate the opium trade.
China emerged victorious from the Opium Wars, thereby securing its domination of the opium trade.
China's strict control of the opium trade was undermined by the Opium Wars.
China's attempts to halt the opium trade were the catalyst for the Opium Wars.
questions.correctAnswer: China's attempts to halt the opium trade were the catalyst for the Opium Wars.

questions.passage: Text I - Medieval bathhouses in Europe
questions.question: The main purpose of the text is to describe -
options: the importance of cleanliness in 16th-century Europe
the differences between medieval and 16th-century villages
the practice of public bathing in medieval Europe
the development of sanitary equipment in the medieval home
questions.correctAnswer: the practice of public bathing in medieval Europe

questions.passage: Text I - Medieval bathhouses in Europe
questions.question: It can be inferred from the first paragraph that the existence of public bathhouses explains why -
options: sanitary conditions in medieval villages were very crude
Europeans were healthier in early medieval times than in the 16th century
medieval villagers were poorer than those of the 16th century
there were few municipal bathhouses in 16th-century Europe
questions.correctAnswer: Europeans were healthier in early medieval times than in the 16th century

questions.passage: Text I - Medieval bathhouses in Europe
questions.question: Which of the following is not mentioned in the second paragraph as something people did at the bathhouse?
questions.correctAnswer: exercising

questions.passage: Text I - Medieval bathhouses in Europe
questions.question: According to the third paragraph, bathhouses were no longer used in the 16th century because -
options: people were embarrassed by bodily exposure
it had become too expensive to heat water
questions.correctAnswer: it had become too expensive to heat water

questions.passage: Text I - Medieval bathhouses in Europe
questions.question: According to the last paragraph, 19th-century city officials would have been surprised to know that -
options: medieval towns and villages had been dirty and disorderly
public bathhouses had existed in early medieval times
wealthy people no longer visited bathhouses
no one was using the bathing facilities in poor neighborhoods
questions.correctAnswer: public bathhouses had existed in early medieval times

questions.passage: Text II - Pigeon culture in China
questions.question: The word "breeding" in line 10 could best be replaced by -
questions.correctAnswer: raising

questions.passage: Text II - Pigeon culture in China
questions.question: According to the second paragraph, during the 1970s -
options: the Chinese government did not allow pigeon racing
pigeon culture was important in China
thousands of pigeons were released throughout China
the Beijing Pigeon Association was created
questions.correctAnswer: the Chinese government did not allow pigeon racing

questions.passage: Text II - Pigeon culture in China
questions.question: According to the third paragraph, Sun Mi -
options: is one of China's 7 million registered pigeon breeders
has pigeons living in every room of his house
likes his pigeons so much that he sleeps near them
questions.correctAnswer: likes his pigeons so much that he sleeps near them

questions.passage: Text II - Pigeon culture in China
questions.question: A continuation of the last paragraph would probably discuss -
options: recent increases in the average monthly salary in China
problems of raising pigeons in other countries
hygiene problems caused by pigeon breeding
questions.correctAnswer: hygiene problems caused by pigeon breeding

questions.passage: Text II - Pigeon culture in China
questions.question: An appropriate title for the text would be -
options: China's Pigeon Culture in the Past and Present
The Pigeon Classics and Other Literature About Birds
Sun Mi and the Beijing Pigeon Association
A History of Pigeon Racing in China
questions.correctAnswer: China's Pigeon Culture in the Past and Present

questions.question: In 1948, the United Nations ____ the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which maintains that all people are born free and equal.
questions.correctAnswer: adopted

questions.question: Marie Curie was the first person ____ two Nobel Prizes.
questions.correctAnswer: to win

questions.question: For a short period during his career, painter Pablo Picasso favored a certain ____ of blue called Prussian blue.
questions.correctAnswer: shade

questions.question: For the first six months of its life, an elephant calf relies almost entirely on its mother's milk for ____.
questions.correctAnswer: sustenance

questions.question: After repeated use, knives become ____ and must be sharpened.
questions.correctAnswer: dull

questions.question: As their natural habitat ____, India's wild water buffalo increasingly come into contact with domesticated water buffalo.
questions.correctAnswer: shrinks

questions.question: The ancient Egyptians developed ____ systems that enabled them to grow crops despite a lack of rainfall.
questions.correctAnswer: irrigation

questions.question: Although Elihu Embree was a slave owner himself, he advocated the ____ of slavery.
questions.correctAnswer: abolition

questions.question: By 2000 B.C.E., Akkadian had largely supplanted Sumerian as the spoken language of southern Mesopotamia.
options: From 2000 B.C.E. onward, Akkadian was no longer spoken in southern Mesopotamia, having been replaced by Sumerian.
By 2000 B.C.E., the majority of people in southern Mesopotamia were speaking Akkadian rather than Sumerian.
By 2000 B.C.E., people in southern Mesopotamia were speaking Akkadian as well as Sumerian.
Until 2000 B.C.E., both Akkadian and Sumerian were the spoken languages of southern Mesopotamia.
questions.correctAnswer: By 2000 B.C.E., the majority of people in southern Mesopotamia were speaking Akkadian rather than Sumerian.

questions.question: Even the minority who regretted the demise of the Austro-Hungarian Empire realized it had been inevitable.
options: It is shocking that the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire was brought about by such a small group of people.
A complex set of circumstances that no one could have predicted led to the demise of the Austro-Hungarian Empire.
The disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian Empire was so gradual that it had very little impact on most people's lives.
The fall of the Austro-Hungarian Empire surprised no one, but only a few were displeased when it actually happened.
questions.correctAnswer: The fall of the Austro-Hungarian Empire surprised no one, but only a few were displeased when it actually happened.

questions.question: The 2020 Mastercard Index of Women Entrepreneurs ranked Ghana as a global leader in the advancement of women-owned businesses.
options: Ghana was listed in the 2020 Mastercard Index of Women Entrepreneurs as one of the countries most supportive of women-owned businesses.
According to the 2020 Mastercard Index of Women Entrepreneurs, companies owned by women are particularly successful in Ghana.
In Ghana, women have made impressive gains in every aspect of the business sector, according to the 2020 Mastercard Index of Women Entrepreneurs.
The 2020 Mastercard Index of Women Entrepreneurs recognized Ghana's efforts to eliminate discrimination against businesses owned by women.
questions.correctAnswer: Ghana was listed in the 2020 Mastercard Index of Women Entrepreneurs as one of the countries most supportive of women-owned businesses.

questions.question: Beware of all enterprises that require new clothes. (Henry David Thoreau)
options: New clothes do not necessarily make a new man.
Undertakings that require one to change should be avoided.
questions.correctAnswer: Undertakings that require one to change should be avoided.

questions.passage: Text I - Jacques Cousteau and ocean exploration
questions.question: In line 5, "these media" include -
options: The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau
"We must go and see for ourselves."
questions.correctAnswer: The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau

questions.passage: Text I - Jacques Cousteau and ocean exploration
questions.question: The motto in line 6 reflects Cousteau's -
questions.correctAnswer: passion for discovery

questions.passage: Text I - Jacques Cousteau and ocean exploration
questions.question: According to the second paragraph, undersea stations -
options: can be moved from place to place
help scientists learn about ocean life
questions.correctAnswer: help scientists learn about ocean life

questions.passage: Text I - Jacques Cousteau and ocean exploration
questions.question: The last paragraph mainly discusses -
options: the Society for the Protection of Ocean Life
the threat to sea life posed by pollution
questions.correctAnswer: Cousteau's work to protect oceans

questions.passage: Text I - Jacques Cousteau and ocean exploration
questions.question: According to the last paragraph, Prince Rainier -
options: was one of the founders of the Cousteau Society
gave money to Cousteau's research projects
was responsible for conservation education in Monaco
questions.correctAnswer: helped prevent nuclear dumping

questions.passage: Text II - Science and the culinary arts
questions.question: According to the first paragraph, one of the ways in which science has benefited the visual and performing arts is by -
options: making works of art available to more people
questions.correctAnswer: making works of art available to more people

questions.passage: Text II - Science and the culinary arts
questions.question: "Nevertheless" in line 8 can best be replaced by -
options: Although there are scientific explanations for many cooking techniques
Despite the differences between science and cooking
Because scientific techniques are now used regularly by cooks
Even though there is evidence that science was applied to cooking in the past
questions.correctAnswer: Even though there is evidence that science was applied to cooking in the past

questions.passage: Text II - Science and the culinary arts
questions.question: It can be inferred from the third paragraph that a scientist might use chromatographic methods to -
options: check the structure of the proteins in eggs
explain how certain large molecules are created
find the substances that make fish taste fishy
compare chemical reactions in different types of cooking
questions.correctAnswer: find the substances that make fish taste fishy

questions.passage: Text II - Science and the culinary arts
questions.question: The text mentions complex carbohydrates and proteins (line 18) because -
options: scientists can explain how they affect the taste and smell of food
they are components of food that can be scientifically analyzed
they are good examples of physical and chemical food properties
science brought them to the awareness of culinary artists
questions.correctAnswer: they are components of food that can be scientifically analyzed

questions.passage: Text II - Science and the culinary arts
questions.question: Based on the information in the last paragraph, which of the following is not one of the goals that chefs try to achieve?
options: replacing old culinary tricks with new ones
questions.correctAnswer: replacing old culinary tricks with new ones

questions.question: Peanut butter was once considered a ____ and served only in the finest restaurants.
questions.correctAnswer: delicacy

questions.question: Coral is sometimes used to replace human bone in facial ____ surgery.
questions.correctAnswer: reconstructive

questions.question: Mycenaean, an early form of Greek, was written in a ____ known as Linear B.
questions.correctAnswer: script

questions.question: The waters of Italy's Aniene River have been ____ into irrigation canals and aqueducts, reducing its once impressive waterfall to a small trickle.
questions.correctAnswer: diverted

questions.question: In 2020, sub-Saharan Africa was ____ affected by malaria, with 95% of the world's cases occurring there.
questions.correctAnswer: disproportionately

questions.question: Once plentiful in North America, freshwater fish have become ____ in recent years.
questions.correctAnswer: scarce

questions.question: According to the Montessori educational method, children who are ____ in a task should not be interrupted.
questions.correctAnswer: absorbed

questions.question: Certain theories in quantum physics can be neither proven nor ____.
questions.correctAnswer: refuted

questions.question: The artistic genius of Vivian Maier was revealed only following her death, when her thousands of remarkable photographs came to light.
options: Vivian Maier's large collection of photographs was exhibited only after her death.
The photographs of Vivian Maier, who died at the height of her career, reveal her unique artistic eye.
It wasn't until Vivian Maier died that her many extraordinary photographs were discovered and her great talent was acknowledged.
Vivian Maier's thousands of photographs, most of which were taken towards the end of her life, are admired by many art critics.
questions.correctAnswer: It wasn't until Vivian Maier died that her many extraordinary photographs were discovered and her great talent was acknowledged.

questions.question: An economic slump is often the harbinger of a recession.
options: The longer a recession persists, the more severe its repercussions.
Economic crises and recessions are usually inevitable.
A recession is a particularly acute economic slump.
In many cases, a recession is heralded by a period of economic decline.
questions.correctAnswer: In many cases, a recession is heralded by a period of economic decline.

questions.question: Achieving literacy in Japanese, which uses multiple alphabets, is a formidable undertaking for non-native speakers.
options: Japanese is not easy to write because each of the characters that make up the alphabet is so complex.
The Japanese alphabet consists of so many characters that non-native speakers find it almost impossible to master reading and writing.
Because Japanese has more than one alphabet, speakers of other languages find learning to read and write the language very challenging.
People who study Japanese have trouble distinguishing among the language's many alphabets.
questions.correctAnswer: Because Japanese has more than one alphabet, speakers of other languages find learning to read and write the language very challenging.

questions.question: A key tenet of socialist feminism is that patriarchy and capitalism are intertwined systems that perpetuate the exploitation and subjugation of women.
options: According to socialist feminism, patriarchy and capitalism keep women from fully utilizing their skills.
Socialist feminists argue that capitalism is a modern manifestation of long-standing patriarchal structures.
Socialist feminism asserts that the discrimination and neglect suffered by women stems from capitalism just as much as from patriarchal control.
Central to socialist feminism is the idea that society has taken advantage of and oppressed women through a combination of patriarchy and capitalism.
questions.correctAnswer: Central to socialist feminism is the idea that society has taken advantage of and oppressed women through a combination of patriarchy and capitalism.

questions.passage: Text I - Orchids
questions.question: Which of the following statements about the vanilla plant cannot be understood from the first paragraph?
options: It is used in preparing food.
It is a well-known kind of orchid.
questions.correctAnswer: It has an unpleasant smell.

questions.passage: Text I - Orchids
questions.question: The main purpose of the second paragraph is to -
options: discuss the different places where orchids grow
explain what epiphytes and lithophytes are
discuss why orchids are considered exotic
questions.correctAnswer: discuss the different places where orchids grow

questions.passage: Text I - Orchids
questions.question: In line 6, "exotic" is closest in meaning to -
questions.correctAnswer: unusual

questions.passage: Text I - Orchids
questions.question: The last paragraph is mainly about -
questions.correctAnswer: orchids in Chinese culture

questions.passage: Text I - Orchids
questions.question: According to the text, orchids are used in making all of the following except -
questions.correctAnswer: bark

questions.passage: Text II - Rubik's Cube
questions.question: The main purpose of the first paragraph is to -
options: introduce the life and work of Erno Rubik
describe the structure of the Rubik's Cube
discuss the origins of a popular puzzle
discuss the connection between geometry and puzzles
questions.correctAnswer: discuss the origins of a popular puzzle

questions.passage: Text II - Rubik's Cube
questions.question: The second paragraph mainly discusses the ____ of a Rubik's Cube.
questions.correctAnswer: appearance and manipulations

questions.passage: Text II - Rubik's Cube
questions.question: Based on the information in the second paragraph, a correctly solved Rubik's Cube must have -
options: a red square on six faces
one white corner on each face
nine squares of different colors on one face
one face with nine blue squares
questions.correctAnswer: one face with nine blue squares

questions.passage: Text II - Rubik's Cube
questions.question: It can be inferred from the last paragraph that the Rubik's Cube -
options: did not sell well in the late 1980s
was less successful in Hungary than in other countries
is very different from the Magic Cube
was manufactured with new colors in the 1990s
questions.correctAnswer: did not sell well in the late 1980s

questions.passage: Text II - Rubik's Cube
questions.question: According to the last paragraph, timed competitions -
options: inspired Rubik to design new puzzles
were responsible for Rubik becoming famous
led to renewed interest in the Rubik's Cube
questions.correctAnswer: led to renewed interest in the Rubik's Cube

questions.question: Some scientists believe that modern varieties of wheat are more likely than traditional ones to ____ allergic reactions.
questions.correctAnswer: trigger

questions.question: Camel's milk – which has three times as much vitamin C and ten times as much iron as cow's milk – is highly ____.
questions.correctAnswer: nutritious

questions.question: Although hot springs are usually ____ volcanic activity, there are quite a few on the Australian mainland that are not found in close proximity to a volcano.
questions.correctAnswer: associated with

questions.question: The baobab tree stores enough water in its trunk to sustain it during a ____.
questions.correctAnswer: drought

questions.question: The ancient Egyptians had numerous uses for natron, a mixture of various salts found in ____ along the Nile river.
questions.correctAnswer: abundance

questions.question: Just three weeks after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr., the city of Mainz, Germany, named a street in memory of the ____ civil rights leader.
questions.correctAnswer: slain

questions.question: The purpose of Britain's Road Traffic Reduction Act was to lessen traffic ____.
questions.correctAnswer: congestion

questions.question: Bats are voracious insect eaters, ____ up to 3,500 bugs in a single night.
questions.correctAnswer: devouring

questions.question: Federalism is a political system characterized by the separation of powers between the central government and regional governments.
options: Federalism is most successful when there is close cooperation between the central government and regional governments.
In a federalist system, policies are set by the central government and carried out by regional governments.
Federalism is defined as a central government working together with smaller regional governments.
A federalist system is one in which authority is divided between the central government and regional governments.
questions.correctAnswer: A federalist system is one in which authority is divided between the central government and regional governments.

questions.question: Nineteenth-century novelist Mary Ann Evans assumed the male pseudonym George Eliot to ensure that her works be given due consideration.
options: The novels of Mary Ann Evans, also known as George Eliot, were written at a time when female authors were not given the attention they deserved.
Mary Ann Evans, fearing that her works would otherwise not be taken seriously, adopted the pen name George Eliot.
Mary Ann Evans was one of many female writers who had to adopt male names in order to have their works published.
Mary Ann Evans changed her name to George Eliot because she wanted her novels to appeal to a male audience.
questions.correctAnswer: Mary Ann Evans, fearing that her works would otherwise not be taken seriously, adopted the pen name George Eliot.

questions.question: When calcium oxide is heated to a temperature approaching its melting point, it emits a brilliant white light.
options: Calcium oxide gives off an intense white light when heated almost to its melting point.
As calcium oxide melts, its brilliant white light dulls.
The hotter calcium oxide becomes, the brighter the light it produces.
Calcium oxide is sometimes melted in order to generate bright white light.
questions.correctAnswer: Calcium oxide gives off an intense white light when heated almost to its melting point.

questions.question: The events of St. Francis's life are well chronicled.
options: Most of what we know about St. Francis's life comes from his writings.
The biography of St. Francis is fascinating.
Much has been written about the life of St. Francis.
The works of St. Francis are extremely accurate.
questions.correctAnswer: Much has been written about the life of St. Francis.

questions.passage: Text I - Physical activity and the fitness industry
questions.question: The main purpose of the first paragraph is to discuss ____ the Industrial Revolution.
options: the decrease in physical activity caused by
questions.correctAnswer: the decrease in physical activity caused by

questions.passage: Text I - Physical activity and the fitness industry
questions.question: The main purpose of the second paragraph is to -
options: discuss the origins of the physical culture movement
describe efforts to make fitness a part of everyday life
compare physical activity in the 19th and 20th centuries
explain why the fitness industry is so profitable
questions.correctAnswer: describe efforts to make fitness a part of everyday life

questions.passage: Text I - Physical activity and the fitness industry
questions.question: According to the second paragraph, the physical culture movement -
options: encouraged all people to exercise regularly
succeeded in improving the fitness of all Americans
questions.correctAnswer: encouraged all people to exercise regularly

questions.passage: Text I - Physical activity and the fitness industry
questions.question: Which of the following statements can be inferred from the second paragraph?
options: People are willing to spend money to stay fit.
Exercise studios have become less popular than they were in the 1960s.
People like playing organized sports more than going to a gym.
Many people want to exercise but cannot find something they enjoy.
questions.correctAnswer: People are willing to spend money to stay fit.

questions.passage: Text I - Physical activity and the fitness industry
questions.question: Which of the following is not an answer to the question "Why is this so?" (line 22)?
options: Because people are too busy to exercise.
Because some people do not enjoy exercising.
Because people prefer to do other things in their free time.
Because exercise does not make people healthier.
questions.correctAnswer: Because exercise does not make people healthier.

questions.passage: Text II - A Velocity of Being: Letters to a Young Reader
questions.question: The main purpose of the first paragraph is to -
options: discuss the benefits of reading to children
introduce a book meant to encourage children to read
questions.correctAnswer: introduce a book meant to encourage children to read

questions.passage: Text II - A Velocity of Being: Letters to a Young Reader
questions.question: In the second paragraph, Solnit -
options: suggests that books should be selected carefully
discusses the relationship between a book's architecture and its contents
describes the benefits that reading can provide
questions.correctAnswer: describes the benefits that reading can provide

questions.passage: Text II - A Velocity of Being: Letters to a Young Reader
questions.question: In the second paragraph, Solnit compares books to all of the following except -
questions.correctAnswer: friends

questions.passage: Text II - A Velocity of Being: Letters to a Young Reader
questions.question: The main purpose of the last paragraph is to -
options: discuss the role that books played in Solnit's childhood
explore a less positive aspect of reading
discuss Solnit's difficult experiences as a child
show how books teach children to love
questions.correctAnswer: discuss the role that books played in Solnit's childhood

questions.passage: Text II - A Velocity of Being: Letters to a Young Reader
questions.question: "There" (line 23) refers to Solnit's -
questions.correctAnswer: tower
